description: Borrowed from French conclave, from Latin conclāve (“room that may be locked up”), from con- (combining form of cum (“with”)) + clāvis (“key”).

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A closed meeting in which the elector cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church choose a new pope.
(Roman Catholicism) The set of apartments in which the elector cardinals are secluded while a conclave takes place.
(Roman Catholicism) The group of cardinals involved in a conclave.
(by extension) A private meeting; a closed or secret assembly.
